titleStmt.title: Reliability of the European Society of Human Reproduction and Embryology/European Society for Gynaecological Endoscopy and American Society for Reproductive Medicine classification systems for congenital uterine anomalies detected using three-dimensional ultrasonography

affiliation.orgName: Department of Oncological Gynecology, Gynecology and Obstetrics
European Society of Human Reproduction and Embryology 31st Annual Congress

analytic.title: Reliability of the European Society of Human Reproduction and Embryology/European Society for Gynaecological Endoscopy and American Society for Reproductive Medicine classification systems for congenital uterine anomalies detected using three-dimensional ultrasonography

biblStruct.note: Received April 11, 2015; revised May 29, 2015; accepted June 8, 2015;

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Objective: To estimate the inter-rater/intrarater reliability of the European Society of Human Reproduction and Embryology/European Society for Gynaecological Endoscopy (ESHRE-ESGE) classification of congenital uterine malformations and to compare the results obtained with the reliability of the American Society for Reproductive Medicine (ASRM) classification supplemented with additional morphometric criteria.
Design: Reliability/agreement study.
Setting: Private clinic.
Patient(s): Uterine malformations (n ¼ 50 patients, consecutively included) and normal uterus (n ¼ 62 women, randomly selected) constituted the study.

These were classified based on real-time three-dimensional ultrasound single volume transvaginal (or transrectal in the case of virgins, 4 cases) ultrasonography findings, which were assessed by an expert rater based on the ESHRE-ESGE criteria.
The samples were obtained from women of reproductive age.
Intervention(s): Unprocessed three-dimensional datasets were independently evaluated offline by two experienced, blinded raters using both classification systems.
Main Outcome Measure(s): The k-values and proportions of agreement.

Result(s): Standardized interpretation indicated that the ESHRE-ESGE system has substantial/good or almost perfect/very good reliability (k >0.60 and >0.80), but the interpretation of the clinically relevant cutoffs of k-values showed insufficient reliability for clinical use (k < 0.90), especially in the diagnosis of septate uterus.
The ASRM system had sufficient reliability (k > 0.95).
The low reliability of the ESHRE-ESGE system may lead to a lack of consensus about the management of common uterine malformations and biased research interpretations.
uring the past 3 decades, the management of uterine malformations has been based on the American Society for Reproductive Medicine (ASRM) classification (1)(2)(3)(4).
It seems (5-7) that only patients with a class V anomaly (septate uterus) according to the ASRM criteria derive reproductive benefits after surgical correction (8,9).

Effective evaluation of the clinical relevance, prevalence, and therapeutic outcomes of different morphological classes of uterine anomalies (8)(9)(10)(11)(12)(13)(14) is hindered by the subjective interpretation of the original ASRM criteria (15)(16)(17).

Therefore (18), for more than a decade, additional morphometric criteria obtained using endoscopy (19), ultrasonography, and other imaging tools (16,20) have been used to supplement the original ASRM classification.
However, there is no international or interdisciplinary agreement on their application (16,(19)(20)(21)(22)(23), and no quantitative criteria have been formally endorsed by the ASRM.

As an alternative to the ASRM classification, the European Society of Human Reproduction and Embryology/ European Society for Gynaecological Endoscopy (ESHRE-ESGE) classification of M€ ullerian anomalies was recently proposed on the basis of the opinions of local experts (24).
To ensure the appropriate management of uterine malformations (3), the classification system used must have adequate inter-rater and intrarater reliability and agreement (25,26).
Three-dimensional (3D) ultrasonography has been found to be a highly accurate (22,27,28) and reliable supplementary method to the ASRM classification (16).
This imaging method appears to be ideal for diagnosing and classifying uterine anomalies using the ESHRE-ESGE system (4).
The reliability and agreement of the ESHRE-ESGE classification system have not yet been determined.

Therefore, the main objective of this study was to estimate the inter-rater and intrarater reliability of the ESHRE-ESGE classification of common congenital uterine malformations and to compare the results obtained with the reliability of the ASRM classification supplemented with additional morphometric criteria (22)(23)(24).

An additional objective of the study was to assess the reliability of the 3D ultrasonographic measurements used to classify the following: internal fundal indentation, and external cleft and uterine wall thickness.
We estimated the relative risk (RR) of disagreement of the ESHRE-ESGE system with the ASRM system, and the potential clinical implications and weaknesses of each system in terms of reliability.

This study of the reliability and agreement of the ASRM and ESHRE-ESGE classification systems for congenital uterine malformations and the reliability of the measurements of applicable criteria was carried out as a part of a larger prospective study evaluating the use of ultrasonography for the screening, diagnosis, and classification of M€ ullerian duct anomalies.
A report from the first phase of this project has been recently presented (23).
The entire project, including the reliability and agreement testing, was approved by the local ethics committee (KBET/236/B/2013).

Nonpregnant women who were aged >18 and <45 years were consecutively enrolled in the main study between June and September 2013 in a private medical center (Ludwin and Ludwin Gynecology, Krakow, Poland).

The specific exclusion criteria (unknown pregnancy, menopause, malignant neoplasms, specific benign lesions, and uterine surgeries) and the enrollment process have been described in a previous report (23).

The 3D volumes were acquired using transvaginal (or transrectal in the case of virgins, 4 cases) examination with the Voluson E8 Expert BT12 ultrasound system (GE Healthcare Ultrasound), the volumetric transvaginal probes (GE RIC 5-9 MHz 3D/4D; GE Healthcare Ultrasound), and the 3D Static HDlive Surface Render Mode software (GE, Healthcare Ultrasound) at the maximum quality setting.

Volume acquisition was performed between days 17 and 25 of the menstrual cycle in a standardized manner at a maximum sweep angle of 180 after obtaining a sagittal view of the uterus (the approximate angle between the ultrasound beam and the uterine axis was 90 ; with the ultrasound probe held steady, the examiner asked the patients to hold their breath and refrain from moving) (23,29,30).
If the uterus was too wide to be scanned in its entirety in the sagittal view, the probe was rotated by 90 and volume acquisition was performed after obtaining the required cross-section (29).
Women with irregular cycles and amenorrhea, those on hormonal contraception, and intrauterine device (IUD) users were diagnosed regardless of the day of the cycle outside the period of menstruation.
All 3D volumes were recorded using the ultrasound machine for offline analysis.
All the records were numbered, and the name and clinical information of the patients were removed.
The modified records were then copied to a storage device (USB flash; Toshiba) and used for the evaluation of inter-rater and intrarater reliability and agreement.
The raters evaluated unprocessed, single 3D volumes of the uterus.
It is difficult to decide the sample and population most suitable for the study of reliability of the systems.
The populations were derived from the general public or specific health care centers and after initial screening contain varying proportions of malformations (4.6%-91%) (13,31).
The dataset of consecutively included women may not contain a representative number of malformations in terms of the diversity of anomalies.

Thus, we decided to include $50% of the 3D volumes obtained from women who were diagnosed with congenital uterine malformations and $50% from women with a normal uterus, as determined using the ESHRE-ESGE classification system (the main objective of reliability estimation) by rater 0 (A.L.).
Because the study was explorative and the reliability estimates were unknown (reliability of the ESHRE-ESGE system), formal sample size determination was not conducted.
However, we assumed that 100 subjects would be sufficient to obtain precise reliability coefficients (32).
To account for the risk of inconclusive results by raters A and B, we initially assumed that the number of subjects would be increased by 10%.

The final dataset was composed of 3D volumes from 50 consecutively enrolled patients with uterine anomalies, as determined using the ESHRE-ESGE system, and 62 women who were determined to have a normal uterus according to the ESHRE-ESGE system and were selected from the main study by computerized randomization (www.randomizer.org).
Two experienced raters participated in this study (both were experts; level 3 according to the European Federation of Societies for Ultrasound in Medicine and Biology, www.efsumb.org)
Raters A (I.L.) and B (M.K.) had similar high skills in the application of 3D ultrasonography and the diagnosis of congenital uterine malformations.
Both use the same ultrasound equipment in their everyday practice as that used in the study.
Before the study, the raters underwent training with the principal investigator/ rater 0 (A.L.).

The training included joint assessment of 3D volumes, acquisition of coronal views, measurement of anatomical benchmarks (internal fundal indentation, external cleft and myometrial thickness; Supplemental Fig. 1, available online), and use of the surface HDlive render mode.

Raters A and B independently evaluated each dataset (the stored unprocessed volumes of 3D transvaginal ultrasonographs) obtained using the same ultrasound machine (Voluson E8 Expert BT12; GE Healthcare Ultrasound), during a 3-day diagnostic session, without a strict time limit for the assessment of single volumes.
The raters were blinded to the results of rater 0 (A.L.) and those of the other rater.

For estimation of the intrarater reliability, rater A, who was blinded to her own previous results, evaluated the same unprocessed 3D volumes 2 weeks after the first evaluation to eliminate a recollection bias.
No clinical data of the patients were available to the raters.
Multiplanar views, final nonrendered sagittal sections (obtained using tomographic ultrasound imaging), and surface HDlive-rendered coronal views of the uterus were used.

Gradient light and HDlive render settings were used freely to optimize the views of the uterine cavity/endometrium, myometrium, endometrial-myometrial junction, interstitial portions of the Fallopian tubes, and external uterine contour.
Specific features of the uterus were subjectively evaluated to detect congenital malformations; internal and external fundal cleft indentations, if present, were measured (23).

The length of the internal indentation/partition was determined by measuring the distance between the interostial line (or the internal intercornual line if the internal cornua of the uterine cavity were above the interostial line) and a parallel line running through the lowest point of the internal indentation/partition in the lower part of the uterus (22,23,29,30).
The depth of the external cleft was determined by measuring the distance between the intercornual line and the lowest point of the cleft (22,23).
The measurements were taken after obtaining a coronal view with visible intramural parts of both Fallopian tubes (16,22,23,29,30).
The uterine wall thickness was measured to classify congenital defects according to the ESHRE-ESGE classification (23,24).
This was in agreement with the temporary recommendation for the measurement (34,35).
The raters performed a single measurement of each parameter.

The assessment of the reliability of classification systems for uterine malformations has been broken down into three key clinical abilities: [1] ability to distinguish congenital defects from normal anatomical characteristics; [2] ability to distinguish septate uterus (a potentially manageable defect) from other malformations and the normal uterus; and [3] ability to provide a detailed catalogue of various malformations (23).
Analyses were carried out using StatsDirect statistical software version 2.7.9 (StatsDirect Ltd.) and SPSS for Windows version 16.0 (SPSS Inc.).
Continuous variables (measurements of internal fundal indentation, external cleft, and uterine wall thickness) were analyzed for normal distribution using the Shapiro-Wilk test.
These variables were found to be nonnormally distributed, and were expressed as median values with lower and upper quartiles, along with the minimum and maximum values.

Inter-rater and intrarater variation in the measurements of the main benchmarks (the three variables) were analyzed by calculating the SDs of the differences in the measurements taken by rater A (first assessment) and rater B, and in the first and second measurements taken by rater A. The mean differences and limits of agreement were plotted.
Scatter plots were used to create a graphical representation of agreement (36).
The inter-rater and intrarater reliability of measurements (continuous variables) were expressed as intraclass correlation coefficients in a one-way random model (1.1).
The intraclass correlation coefficients were interpreted as follows: very poor, <0.70; poor, 0.70-0.90;
moderate, 0.90-0.95;
and very good, >0.99 (25,37).
The results of the differentiation between specific classes of uterine anomalies using the ESHRE-ESGE and ASRM systems (nominal scales) were presented in contingency tables.
The inter-rater and intrarater reliability/agreement of the two classifications were evaluated using the kappa (k) statistic and proportions of agreement (25,38).

The k-value was interpreted to be clinically sufficient for the categorization of anomalies according to the diagnostic/ catalogueing aims (anomalous vs. normal uterus: sufficient, >0.9 and insufficient, <0.9), and for important clinical issues, such as potential use in selecting patients for surgery (septate uterus vs. other anomalies: sufficient, >0.95; insufficient, <0.95).
Alternatively, the k-value was interpreted with regard to reporting the reliability/strength of agreement as follows: poor, <0.20; fair, 0.21-0.40;
moderate, 0.41-0.60;
substantial/good, 0.61-0.80;
and almost perfect/very good, 0.81-1.00

The RR with 95% confidence interval (CI) and P value (41) were calculated for disagreements in the differentiation of septate uterus from other anomalies and normal uterus, differentiation of anomalous uteri from normal uteri, and differentiation of specific categories according to the ESHRE-ESGE classification relative to the ASRM classification.
A P value of %.05 was considered to indicate statistical significance.
The process of patient enrollment in the main study, and the patients' clinical and demographic characteristics have been previously reported (23).
Raters A and B each conducted a single evaluation/measurement of the same 112 volumes during the 3-day session.
After 2 weeks, rater A assessed the same volumes again.

Among the uterus volumes measured, 67 of 112 (59.8%) were obtained from women who had never been pregnant; 45 of 112 (40.2%) were obtained from women who had been pregnant in the past; and 86 of 112 (76.8%) were obtained from nulliparas.
No samples were obtained from women with amenorrhea or an IUD; 4 of 112 (3.6%) were obtained from women with irregular cycles; and 6 of 112 (5.4%) were obtained from those on hormonal contraception.
One hundred eight datasets were acquired using transvaginal ultrasonography, and 4 of 112 (3.6%) datasets were from virgins, who underwent transrectal ultrasonography.
The raters had no inconclusive results.
The results of the measurements of the main benchmarks by raters A and B for the classification of congenital uterine anomalies are presented in Supplemental Table 1, available online.
The inter-rater agreement for the measurements is shown in Supplemental Figure 2, available online.
The inter-rater intraclass correlation coefficient (1.1) for internal fundal indentation was >0.99 (0.991; 95% CI 0.987-0.994),
and those for external cleft and uterine wall thickness were 0.95-0.99
respectively).
Similar intraclass correlation coefficients were obtained for the intrarater reliability of the measurements.
Supplemental Table 2, available online, shows the mean differences and limits of agreement for the two measurements by rater A, and for the measurements by raters A and B.

div.head: Reliability and Agreement with Regard to the Diagnosis of Congenital Uterine Anomalies

p.s: The classification of the uterine morphology according to the ESHRE-ESGE and ASRM systems is presented in Table 1, and the classification of categories that are clinically important (septate uterus vs. other anomalies and normal uterus, and anomalous vs. normal uterus) is shown in Table 2.
There were few disagreements between the two raters and between the same rater at different times with regard to all categories (Tables 1 and 2).

The percentage of disagreement in the differentiation between septate uterus and other anomalies using the ASRM criteria was very low (0.9%, one case) in comparison with that for the ESHRE-ESGE criteria (intrarater, 8%; inter-rater, 11.6%).

The RRs for disagreements in the recognition of septate uterus using the ESHRE-ESGE classification relative to the ASRM classification were significantly high (RR for intrarater disagreement: 9.0, 95% CI 1.2-70, P¼ .04;
RR for inter-rater disagreement: 13, 95% CI 1.8-98, P¼ .04).

The RRs for inter-rater and intrarater disagreement with regard to the determination of anomalous versus normal uterus and specific classes were lower in the case of the ESHRE-ESGE criteria than in the case of the ASRM criteria, but the difference was not statistically significant.

Inter-rater and intrarater reliability were higher (higher k-values) for the diagnoses based on the ASRM criteria than for the diagnoses based on the ESHRE-ESGE criteria in the case of all the categories (specific classes of anomalies, recognition of septate uterus, and differentiation between anomalous and normal uteri) (Table 2).

This study is the first to estimate the reliability/agreement with regard to the diagnosis of congenital uterine anomalies using the ESHRE-ESGE criteria (24), and to compare it with the reliability/agreement of diagnoses obtained using the ASRM classification supplemented by morphometric criteria (16,21-23, 29, 30, 34, 35).

The study showed that the ESHRE-ESGE classification has insufficient reliability for making individual and clinically important decisions (25) in the management of congenital malformations of the uterus, in particular septate uterus (k < 0.9).

The reliability of the ASRM classification supplemented with morphometric criteria was better than that of the ESHRE-ESGE classification for the diagnosis of septate uterus (k > 0.95; substantial vs. moderate inter-rater reliability by the lower limit of the CI of the k statistic), for the differentiation between anomalous and normal uteri (k > 0.9; substantial vs. moderate inter-rater reliability by the lower limit of the CI), and for the general classification of uterine morphology (k > 0.9; almost perfect vs. substantial interrater reliability by the lower limit of the CI; Supplemental Table 3, available online) (25,39,40,42).

The RRs of interrater and intrarater disagreement in the recognition of septate uterus using the ESHRE-ESGE criteria were significantly higher (13Â and 9Â, respectively) than those for the ASRM system.

An additional concern is that the ESHRE-ESGE system was found to have insufficient clinical reliability even under conditions (offline 3D analysis) that limited the influence of additional factors that can generate variability (37,43) and artifacts (44), which are present in clinical practice.
The weakest point of the ESHRE-ESGE classification was potentially the most important one from the clinical point of view, namely, the differentiation of a septate uterus from a normal uterus.
In the case of this category, sufficient reliability (k > 0.95) is expected from the classification system (25).
In the ASRM classification, the most inconsistencies were related to the identification of arcuate uterus (Table 1).

It seems that the reliability of the ESHRE-ESGE system was lower than that of the ASRM system due to the following reasons: [1] the introduction of an additional benchmark (uterine wall thickness) and relative cutoffs (percentage of uterine wall thickness; <50%, >50%) for the recognition of distortion in the outer and inner uterine structures; and [2] the design of the ESHRE-ESGE classification, which does not include arcuate uterus as a category (Supplemental Fig. 3, available online).

From a clinical point of view, the reliability of the measurement of uterine wall thickness under ideal offline analysis conditions seems to be insufficient (moderate reliability based on the lower limit of the CI) because in clinical practice, the thickness of the wall, even when measured in the same place, is more changeable and depends on a number of variables typical for the specific ultrasound examination (differing pressure applied on the probe; Supplemental Fig. 4, available online) or other independent factors (cyclical contractions of the myometrium; Supplemental Fig. 5, available online) (45).

This is an additional reason (beside the ESHRE-ESGE paradox: slight internal indentation may be recognized as a malformation, whereas a larger indentation may be recognized as a normal uterus depending on the uterine wall thickness) (46).
The uterine wall thickness should not be a benchmark for the diagnosis of congenital uterine malformations (23,30,34).
We believe that the omission of the arcuate uterus as a category from the ESHRE-ESGE system is premature and does not consider the consequences of the application of new morphometric criteria.
In the ASRM classification, the arcuate uterus serves as a type of buffer zone between the diagnoses of normal uterus and septate uterus (Supplemental Fig. 3).

The ESHRE-ESGE system omits this diagnosis as a separate class and introduces a new confusing criterion of dysmorphic uterus (subclass U1c; similar definition as for normal uterus) ( 24), which we have excluded from the study in accordance with our earlier recommendation (23).

We believe that the cutoffs and benchmarks in an ideal classification system should take into account the realities related to the distribution of morphological characteristics in the population (Figs. 1 and 2) and the potential use of the classification in the management of congenital uterine malformations (3,23).

The strengths of the present study are [1] its design, which is based on the main prospective study, with consecutively included anomalies and randomly selected volumes of normal uteri; [2] the participation of experienced, blinded raters; [3] the elimination of additional sources of variability; and [4] data analysis and reporting that closely reflect the currently recommended reporting standards for reliability/agreement studies (Guidelines for Reporting Reliability and Agreement Studies) (25).

Considering that we eliminated additional sources of variability, the reliability estimates obtained for the ESHRE-ESGE and ASRM classifications in the present study should be considered as the upper limits, which are difficult to achieve in clinical practice (37).

Another limitation of the study is the sample size of the specific subjects (especially rare or complex anomalies) and of the raters, which is suitable for an explorative study on common morphological forms of the uterus.
The inclusion of other raters might have yielded other results.

The risk of a selection bias (the study sample was not from the general public, although anomalous and morphological forms of the normal uterus of consecutively enrolled women were used) was highlighted in the main study, and the distribution of defects reflects their prevalence in clinical practice (23).

The distribution of normal and anomalous uteri according to the ESHRE-ESGE classification ($50:50 ratio) was arbitrarily chosen, and is appropriate for specialized centers that treat high-risk populations, often after the initial screening tests (prevalence, upper limit of 95% CI ¼ 48.8) (13).
The only available study (16) on the reliability of classifying congenital uterine malformations is one that evaluated the reproducibility of 3D ultrasonographic diagnoses.
This previous study reported a high level of inter-rater reliability (k ¼ 0.97, 95% CI 0.94-1.0)
for the ASRM classification supplemented with morphometric criteria.
Disagreement was observed in 1 of 83 (1.2%) cases with regard to the differentiation between septate and arcuate uteri (16).

Another study (47) draws attention to the poor international inter-rater agreement in the differentiation of septate, arcuate, and normal uteri using hysteroscopy, which is a suboptimal test (accuracy, <0.9) (13,48) for the diagnosis of uterine malformations.

The most important clinical implications of our study are the high RR for inter-rater and intrarater disagreements in the recognition of septate uterus using the ESHRE-ESGE criteria and the clinically insufficient reliability of this system in the management of patients with septate uterus.

In patient care, this may lead to underdiagnosis or overdiagnosis, the risk of different clinical decisions by different doctors or by the same doctor at different times, and the risk of the patient refusing to undergo treatment in the case of septate uterus, especially in women in recurrent abortion or overtreatment of the normal uterus.

Simultaneously, the study depicts the potential causes of insufficiency and makes recommendations for improving the reliability by eliminating the use of uterine wall thickness as a benchmark, and the introduction to the ESHRE-ESGE classification of a category that represents the transitional state between the septate uterus and normal uterus.
In light of previous reports (23,30,34), this study highlights the need for improvements in the definitions and criteria of the ESHRE-ESGE system.

The study indicates that the design of classification systems should take into account their reliability testing before coming to an expert consensus, as well as recommendations for wide use and application in clinical practice.

Future research should focus on redefinition of the ESHRE-ESGE criteria and reliability testing of the modified criteria, first on offline 3D ultrasonographic models, and then in real-time, in conjunction with clinically relevant cutoffs for the differentiation between septate uterus and other uterine defects (23,(48)(49)(50).
Finally, the ASRM should endorse quantitative criteria for common uterine malformations based on available and future research, and clinical utility.

In conclusion, the reliability of the ESHRE-ESGE system may be insufficient for the management of common uterine malformations, in particular, septate uterus, despite the use of an optimal diagnostic test (3D transvaginal ultrasonography).
The use of the ASRM classification supplemented with simple morphometric criteria may be preferred, if their high reliability can be confirmed real time in a larger sample size.

The authors thank Justyna Stefaniak (M.Sc., mathematician, biostatistician) of Data Management and Statistical Analysis (Krakow, Poland) for help with the data processing and initial statistical analysis.
We also thank Weronika Maciaszek, Marzena Stryjak, and Monika Szczepanek (from Ludwin and Ludwin Gynecology) for their help in data collection.
Finally, we thank Oxford Science Editing Ltd. for revising the language of this manuscript.

SUPPLEMENTAL FIGURE Potential causes of insufficient reliability of the European Society of Human Reproduction and Embryology/European Society for Gynaecological Endoscopy (ESHRE-ESGE) systems in the diagnosis of septate uterus and differentiation between an anomalous and normal uteri; (i) 50% of the uterine wall thickness is a relative benchmark; (ii) exclusion of the arcuate uterus as a separate category provides two classes (ESHRE-ESGE: normal and septate) instead of three classes (American Society for Reproductive Medicine [ASRM]: normal, arcuate, and septate) for the same deformity (internal indentation); (iii) results, with a frequent need for differentiation between variations within the norm.
In the ASRM classification, the differentiation is between relatively rarer transitional forms.

Local changes in the uterine muscle tension during real-time diagnosis.

A uterus that is judged to be normal by the American Society for Reproductive Medicine (ASRM) system and (left scan) septate by the European Society of Human Reproduction and Embryology/European Society for Gynaecological Endoscopy (ESHRE-ESGE) system (middle scan) meets the criteria for normal after a few minutes according to the ESHRE-ESGE criteria (right scan; uterine wall thickness) as well.
This undermines the recognition of small deformations (internal indentation <1 cm) as indications of congenital anomalies.

analytic.title: Mullerian anomalies: a proposed classification (an analysis of 144 cases)
